Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Hormones as Mediators of Life History Tradeoffs Over Evolutionary Time

Tradeoffs between the future well-being of an organism and investment in offspring represent a hallmark of biological diversity. Much research has focused either on the evolutionary reasons to expect certain tradeoffs or the physiological mediation of individual life history traits. Recent research suggests that individual hormones regulate multiple life history traits. However, it is unclear whether the multifaceted role hormones play represents an adaptation, or an unavoidable result of a limited number of available physiological mechanisms. The research will compare the results of evolutionary simulations to novel empirical data to test these contrasting hypotheses. The proposed research makes use of butterflies as a model due to the extensive natural history information available for many species, combined with their experimental tractability.

This research represents a potentially transformative contribution to the understanding of how hormones mediate life history tradeoffs, and how these relationships evolve. In addition to the research aims, the fellow will design a blog incorporating stop-motion animation to present training objectives to a wider audience in an entertaining format. The fellow will mentor over ten undergraduates who will have opportunities to develop related independent projects. During the final year of funding, the fellow will be involved in teaching undergraduate and graduate courses. A team of mentors will train the fellow in new laboratory and field skills, mathematical modeling, and computer programming.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This fellowship award to Eli M. Swanson was entitled, “Hormones as Mediators of Life History Tradeoffs Over Evolutionary Time,” and had three main components: research, teaching and mentoring, and training. The research described here was largely conducted at the University of Minnesota (UMN), as was the teaching component of the fellowship award. The training component included training in research, teaching, and mentoring undergraduates.

Hormones regulate changes occurring over the lifetime of a single organism, and many traits regulated by hormones are important to determining variation in survival and reproduction. This variation in survival and reproduction directly impact heritable changes in traits over time, and heritable change over time in many species produces the variation we see in nature. Despite our ever-improving understanding of each piece of this puzzle, we still lack a clear view of the puzzle as a whole. The purpose of this research project was thus to improve our understanding of how the role of hormones in development relates to evolutionary variation among species. Butterflies make excellent study organisms for this research: we know what they eat, as well as where and how they live their lives. We can also easily rear large numbers of some species in captivity, and previous research suggests that they respond easily to hormone manipulation. We integrated three approaches: measurement of phenotypic responses to hormone manipulation, measurement of genetic responses to hormone manipulation, and simulation modeling. For the first approach we applied synthetic juvenile hormone, an important developmental hormone in insects, to butterfly abdomens after they emerged as adults. We used this manipulation to test hypotheses about the evolution, development, and phenotypic plasticity of important traits like offspring number, offspring size, and lifespan using butterflies as a model system. For the second approach we used the same hormone manipulation, but measured differences in gene expression resulting from the manipulation to better understand the precise physiological processes linking the phenotypic responses to juvenile hormone manipulation. Our third approach involved using computer simulations to better understand how these two approaches connect over evolutionary time. Two papers addressing these objectives are currently in preparation, with two others planned. One contributed book chapter and six peer-reviewed journal articles have been published during the tenure of this award; Swanson was the primary author on three, and a co-author on three. The research resulting from this award will contribute to our broader understanding of how hormone variation influencing growth, reproduction, and aging relates to evolution.

Teaching was also a major part of this fellowship. In the final year of the fellowship, Swanson focused on three teaching opportunities. Swanson was invited to teach a course called Nature of Life at UMN. Nature of Life is a freshman orientation course, and the first experience most undergraduates at the College of Biological Sciences at UMN have with faculty. Nature of Life gave Swanson the opportunity to interact with large numbers of both students and faculty in a variety of situations, and with pedagogical training Swanson pursued during the award, prepared him to teach as sole instructor a freshman seminar he designed called “Evidence-based living.” In the final spring of the award, Swanson co-taught a writing-intensive animal behavior course with his primary mentor for the award, Dr. Emilie Snell-Rood. During the award tenure, Swanson also published a blog focusing on making difficult science widely digestible, and participated in educational outreach activities such as a butterfly natural history presentation at the Minnesota State Fair every year of the fellowship. Swanson has continued both outreach activities since the conclusion of the fellowship award.

The training component of the project allowed Swanson a variety of effective and unique opportunities. Swanson took advantage of a variety of training opportunities geared toward research, such as coursework, seminars, and direct mentorship from a variety of collaborators and mentors. One of the most important examples includes online courses, discussion groups, and personal collaboration in bioinformatics and genomics, opening up this research area to Swanson as a new specialty. Until the onset of this project, he had had no practical exposure to genomics or bioinformatics techniques, and given his current postdoctoral position in population genomics, this aspect of the project has been a highly effective training opportunity. Interactions with a variety of mentors, a great deal of directed reading, both research- and teaching-related seminars, and coursework resulted in major additions to Swanson’s scientific ‘toolbox.’ During this award, Swanson has gained a great deal of both philosophical and practical experience, particularly with regard to integrating modeling and biology, bioinformatics, curriculum development, teaching with writing, and student mentoring in research.
